text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] be a [mathjaxinline]4\times 3[/mathjaxinline] matrix. There is a specific vector [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] for which you can conclude the equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = v[/mathjaxinline] has a solution, even without knowing anything else about [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline]. What is this vector [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: The equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline] always has at least one solution, namely [mathjaxinline]x = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]. Since [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] has 4 columns, [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] is the zero vector in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^4[/mathjaxinline] specifically.
